pr_title: Exploit blocking FAST_POLL for eventfd reads

timeline.bodyText: @njhill is this safe using a shared read buffer with multiple io ring event loops..?
timeline.author: johnou

replies.bodyText: @johnou yeah should be save I guess, however it's odd :)
replies.author: 1Jo1

replies.bodyText: Well there is no sync across event loops so I don't see how this is safe.. is the operation atomic or something?
replies.author: johnou

replies.bodyText: @johnou its safe because we basically don't care about what we read... we just need to read.
replies.author: normanmaurer

replies.bodyText: @johnou yep what @normanmaurer said :) ... though I wonder might it be better for it to be padded, not sure if there are any false sharing implications
replies.author: njhill

replies.bodyText: @njhill yeah... maybe just use one per EventLoop, 8 more bytes really don't matter :)
replies.author: normanmaurer

replies.bodyText: Technically 16 bytes with the instance field :)
replies.author: njhill

replies.bodyText: true... that said thats fine as well :D
replies.author: normanmaurer

replies.bodyText: thanks for making the change, for me it was a huge code smell 👍
replies.author: johnou

timeline.message: Keep eventfd read buffer per event loop rather than sharing globally

timeline.author: normanmaurer

timeline.message:
Exploit blocking FAST_POLL for eventfd reads

Motivation

If we make eventfd blocking then read can take the place of poll+read

Modification

Make eventfd blocking, use READ instead of POLLIN, allocating a static
64bit buffer to read into

Result

Fewer kernel roundtrips for event loop wakeups
Keep eventfd read buffer per event loop rather than sharing globally
Rename JNI blocking eventfd method, remove now-unused eventFdRead method
